In addition, the warm front remained nearly stationary through much of the event, which resulted in echo training and flash flooding across Lenawee and Monroe counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported tree limbs blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of Wednesday, June 21st, rapid thunderstorm development occurred across the southern two tiers of counties in southeast Michigan. The strongest storms were focused along the leading edge of a very unstable airmass associated with a warm front.  As the storms interacted with the surface warm front, the storms began to immediately rotate. Several circulations were noted at any given time. One tornado, rated at F0 intensity, touched down near Addison in Lenawee County. The severe thunderstorms resulted in a mix of high wind and large hail, with several reports of hail the size of golf balls. In addition, the warm front remained nearly stationary through much of the event, which resulted in echo training and flash flooding across Lenawee and Monroe counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of Monday June 19th, an upper level disturbance and associated cold front moved into the region and created a reasonably unstable environment. A decent number of severe weather events were noted in the relatively short-lived episode. These included mainly hail of 3/4 to 1 inch in diameter, but also spotty wind damage and a waterspout in western lake erie. The storms were multi-cellular in nature. Several short-lived supercells managed to produce hail up to the size of golf balls, winds up to 70 MPH, and one of the supercells eventually produced the waterspout.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated wind gusts to 70 MPH.

A 10 year old girl was injured when lightning struck a tree along a sidewalk as her and her grandmother were heading for their vehicle as a storm approached. She was knocked over and was found unconcious and not breathing. She was revived enroute to the hospital and is expected to recover fully. The grandmother was knocked over but suffered no other injuries.
A few strong storms developed ahead of an upper level disturbance.  The strongest storm produced penny sized hail in Montmorency County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in a humid airmass with cold air aloft.  This allowed some storms to produce severe hail.   Hailstones as large as ping-pong balls fell in Cadillac.

A potent upper level disturbance brought very cold air aloft into the northern Great Lakes.  Abundant sunshine in the morning provided the fuel to power numerous thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Thanks to the cold air aloft, a number of these storms produced large hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another day of pop-up afternoon thunderstorms, thanks to cold air aloft residing over the Great Lakes region.  One storm produced nickel sized hail in Kalkaska County.

Nearly stationary thunderstorms developed in the pre-dawn hours, directly underneath a slow-moving upper level low pressure system.  Radar estimated that around 4 inches of rain fell in a portion of the Rapid River basin, just north of Kalkaska.  Flooding was enhanced by the failure of a beaver dam on a small creek.  Part of Wood Road was washed out by the high water, and Smith and Holly Roads were also impacted.  Traffic on US-131 at the Rapid River bridge was reduced to one lane for a time, as waters raged close to underside of the bridge.
An upper level disturbance ignited strong thunderstorms across much of Northern Michigan.  Only one storm reached severe levels, dropping quarter sized hail in Gladwin County.

An approaching cold front interacting with an extremely unstable airmass triggered a widespread outbreak of severe weather across west and central Upper Michigan from late afternoon on the 28th to just after sunrise on the 29th. Of the 13 counties in west and central Upper Michigan, only Alger and Keweenaw counties escaped without severe weather, as there were at least 40 individual reports of damaging wind or large hail during the event.  The storms also produced torrential downpours and minor flooding over Gogebic County during the early morning hours of the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few large trees blown down along Highway M-94 just north of the Indian River Bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The July 17th severe weather event would eventually go down as the largest and most destructive of the 2006 severe weather season. Intense thunderstorms fired along and ahead of a cold front working down from the northern Great Lakes and eventually developed into a large MCS by mid evening. The Tri Cities and thumb regions were especially hard hit during this event. Several microbursts actually produced 100 MPH wind gusts across northeast Huron county, causing quite a bit of damage. The outflow created from the storms across the north actually held together long enough to spread south. There were several reports of trees blown down in areas south of M-59, although the damage was minimal when compared to the destruction across the northern parts of the area. Very few reports of hail were received, however, golf ball size hail was reported in Saginaw County. This event caused one death and one injury in Wayne County. A couple was struck by lightning after seeking refuge under a tree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Central dispatch reported a tree blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This 2006 heat wave delivered the hottest weather the region had experienced in at least 4 years. A 5 day stretch of maximum temperatures at or above 90 degrees began on Saturday, July 29th. A blanket of especially high heat and oppressive humidity settled over the area on Monday, July 31st, and remained relentless through Wednesday, August 2nd. Temperatures soared above 90 by noon with heat indices over 100 degrees. Heat indices averaged between 105 and 110 degrees through the entire afternoon. Most significantly, Detroit Metro tied the all time record for the warmest minimum temperature, for any date, when it failed to record a temperature below 80 degrees on July 31st.  This had happened only 3 other times in the previous 136 years of record keeping, and this was the first time in 64 years that it had happened again. Detroit topped out at 97 and set a new high temperature record for August 1st,  tying the old record set in 1988. Little relief was felt during the evening with temperatures not dropping below 90 until 1900 EST. The major power companies in the area reported an all-time record customer demand for power from 1500 to 1600 EDT on the 1st, breaking the record that was set just the day before. Remarkably, very few heat related illnesses occurred during the event. Newspaper articles revealed an extremely high level of awareness and preparedness from the communities across southeast lower Michigan. A large number of cooling centers were made available to those in need as folks reportedly heeded the warnings and took extra precaution. Although area hospitals reported some increase due to heat related illnesses, most were mild and due to heat exhaustion and dehydration. Six cases of heatstroke were confirmed in Washtenaw, Wayne, and Macomb Counties. No heat related deaths were reported.

A cold front moved through the area during the evening of August 2nd and finally brought an end to the five day heat wave that had plagued southeast Michigan. Thunderstorms, a few intense, fired up out ahead of the cold front within the unstable airmass in place across southeast michigan. The severe weather was primarily confined to areas along and just south of the I-69 corridor. This was mainly a wind event with reports of several trees blown down. Most significantly, a tropical-like airmass and repeated rounds of storms along the I-69 corridor caused flash flooding in Lapeer and Sanilac counties, with extensive damages occurring in and around the Brown City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper reported several trees blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm dumped about 3 inches of rain in downtown Detroit. Several underpasses became flooded with several feet of water in the southwest part of the city. A few cars became stranded with motorists calling for help. No damages or injuries were reported.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rains with rates approaching 2 inches per hour over the downtown area. Broadcast Media reported on flooding along I-75 from 5 Mile to 7 Mile Rd. Trained spotters also reported street flooding in Westland and in Canton Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area during the evening of August 2nd and finally brought an end to the five day heat wave that had plagued southeast Michigan. Thunderstorms, a few intense, fired up out ahead of the cold front within the unstable airmass in place across southeast michigan. The severe weather was primarily confined to areas along and just south of the I-69 corridor. This was mainly a wind event with reports of several trees blown down. Most significantly, a tropical-like airmass and repeated rounds of storms along the I-69 corridor caused flash flooding in Lapeer and Sanilac counties, with extensive damages occurring in and around the Brown City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain repeatedly occurred across the same areas and dumped rain at a rate of nearly 2 inches per hour. Doppler radar estimated that 5 inches of rain fell in a west to east swath across southeast Sanilac County, and as much as 10 inches in an isolated area in and around the Brown City area. A cooperative observer in Brown City actually measured 7.35 inches over a 4 hour period on the evening of August 2nd, with an additional eight tenths of an inch falling after midnight during the early morning hours of the 3rd. The most intense rain fell from about 2000 EST on the 2nd to about 0100 EST on the 3rd. Flash flooding began around 2300 EST. Many homes in the Brown City area were heavily damaged by flood waters. The entire town experienced flooding and the city manager reported 220 damage claims filed with the city. At least 3 basements were lost and and a few homes reported nearly $100K in damages. The entire lower half of the high school was flooded with 3 to 5 inches of water. Flood waters reached 3 feet deep in a mobile home park in the city. Around 0200 EST on the 3rd, the flood waters stopped rising, and by noon, the flood waters began to recede. Total property damages were estimated at $1.25M. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area during the evening of August 2nd and finally brought an end to the five day heat wave that had plagued southeast Michigan. Thunderstorms, a few intense, fired up out ahead of the cold front within the unstable airmass in place across southeast michigan. The severe weather was primarily confined to areas along and just south of the I-69 corridor. This was mainly a wind event with reports of several trees blown down. Most significantly, a tropical-like airmass and repeated rounds of storms along the I-69 corridor caused flash flooding in Lapeer and Sanilac counties, with extensive damages occurring in and around the Brown City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper reported that a house had been damaged by fallen power lines. A tree limb, struck by lightning, fell onto the power lines causing them to break and burn a portion of the aluminum siding on the home. The burning tree and arcing power lines sent neighbors to warn the homeowners. Two men received minor injuries (indirect) when they were electrocuted after knocking on the door of the home. Total property damages, including electrical appliances, was roughly estimated at $2.5K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This 2006 heat wave delivered the hottest weather the region had experienced in at least 4 years. A 5 day stretch of maximum temperatures at or above 90 degrees began on Saturday, July 29th. A blanket of especially high heat and oppressive humidity settled over the area on Monday, July 31st, and remained relentless through Wednesday, August 2nd. Temperatures soared above 90 by noon with heat indices over 100 degrees. Heat indices averaged between 105 and 110 degrees through the entire afternoon. Most significantly, Detroit Metro tied the all time record for the warmest minimum temperature, for any date, when it failed to record a temperature below 80 degrees on July 31st.  This had happened only 3 other times in the previous 136 years of record keeping, and this was the first time in 64 years that it had happened again. Detroit topped out at 97 and set a new high temperature record for August 1st,  tying the old record set in 1988. Little relief was felt during the evening with temperatures not dropping below 90 until 1900 EST. The major power companies in the area reported an all-time record customer demand for power from 1500 to 1600 EDT on the 1st, breaking the record that was set just the day before. Remarkably, very few heat related illnesses occurred during the event. Newspaper articles revealed an extremely high level of awareness and preparedness from the communities across southeast lower Michigan. A large number of cooling centers were made available to those in need as folks reportedly heeded the warnings and took extra precaution. Although area hospitals reported some increase due to heat related illnesses, most were mild and due to heat exhaustion and dehydration. Six cases of heatstroke were confirmed in Washtenaw, Wayne, and Macomb Counties. No heat related deaths were reported.

Several lines of thunderstorms moved through Northern Lower Michigan, well ahead of a cold front out to the west.  These storms produced a considerable amount of wind damage as they raced across the region late in the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees and power lines downed.  More than 45 trees were downed at South Higgins Lake State Park, crushing several vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several lines of thunderstorms moved through Northern Lower Michigan, well ahead of a cold front out to the west.  These storms produced a considerable amount of wind damage as they raced across the region late in the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large trees downed in Rose City.  Power poles and lines downed across a road in Lupton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A newspaper reported that a lightning strike had caused a house to burn down. Lightning struck the home on Saturday evening, the 26th, sparking electrical problems. The electrical problem caused the home to go up in flames 24 hours later, at 1830 EST on the 27th. Total property damages were estimated at $100K.

A local newspaper reported that lightning struck a home on Swaffer Rd, causing electrical problems. The family was shocked whenever they touched a grounded object. Firefighters contacted the American Red Cross and found the family of eight a place to stay until electricians could be contacted. Property damages were roughly estimated at around $2.5K.

A 27 year old male was struck by lightning while inside his home. The lightning struck just as he was closing an aluminum storm door that was blown open by the wind. It first hit his backyard and traveled up the porch, to the storm door, and through his body. He was barefoot at the time and the lightning knocked him to the floor in pain. He was unable to talk for awhile but refused to be transported to the hospital. His arm was swollen the following day and his joints remained stiff.

A Local newspaper reported that dense fog caused three rollover crashes involving semi-trucks, one car fire and one other crash on I-69. Officials had to shut down I-69 in both directions between the M-71 exit and the Grand River exit to clean up the crashes. Seven people were injured (indirectly). No one was killed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree downed onto power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper reported that lightning set a barn on fire, causing extensive damage. The barn was 60 by 170 feet located at the Muxlow Dairy Farm on Wilcoz Rd. Trees and power lines down near Gogebic County Airport.
Two to three-inch diameter branches down.  A few trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread frost was reported at many interior locations of western Upper Michigan on the morning of the 10th as temperatures lowered into the mid to upper 20s.

The July 17th severe weather event would eventually go down as the largest and most destructive of the 2006 severe weather season. Intense thunderstorms fired along and ahead of a cold front working down from the northern Great Lakes and eventually developed into a large MCS by mid evening. The Tri Cities and thumb regions were especially hard hit during this event. Several microbursts actually produced 100 MPH wind gusts across northeast Huron county, causing quite a bit of damage. The outflow created from the storms across the north actually held together long enough to spread south. There were several reports of trees blown down in areas south of M-59, although the damage was minimal when compared to the destruction across the northern parts of the area. Very few reports of hail were received, however, golf ball size hail was reported in Saginaw County. This event caused one death and one injury in Wayne County. A couple was struck by lightning after seeking refuge under a tree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported a tree blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area during the evening of August 2nd and finally brought an end to the five day heat wave that had plagued southeast Michigan. Thunderstorms, a few intense, fired up out ahead of the cold front within the unstable airmass in place across southeast michigan. The severe weather was primarily confined to areas along and just south of the I-69 corridor. This was mainly a wind event with reports of several trees blown down. Most significantly, a tropical-like airmass and repeated rounds of storms along the I-69 corridor caused flash flooding in Lapeer and Sanilac counties, with extensive damages occurring in and around the Brown City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain repeatedly occurred across the same areas and dumped rain at a rate of nearly 2 inches per hour. Doppler radar estimated that 6 inches of rain, with locally higher amounts, fell in a west to east swath across north central Lapeer County. The most intense rain fell from about 2000 EST on the 2nd to about 0100 EST on the 3rd. Flash flooding began around 2245 EST. The rain caused mass flooding to area roads. Nearly a dozen roads, between M-90 and Clear Lake Rd, were washed out and had to be closed. Crops were also severely punished. Farmers in the North Branch area reported losing over a million dollars in vegetable and sod crops. One farmer lost 120 acres of sod, estimated at $540K. Another farmer lost 35 acres of onions, estimated at around $200K. Total losses in crops due to the floods were estimated at $1M. Several homes were heavily damaged by flooding on the east side of burnside township. Total property damages, including rebuilding roads, were estimated at $300K. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The July 17th severe weather event would eventually go down as the largest and most destructive of the 2006 severe weather season. Intense thunderstorms fired along and ahead of a cold front working down from the northern Great Lakes and eventually developed into a large MCS by mid evening. The Tri Cities and thumb regions were especially hard hit during this event. Several microbursts actually produced 100 MPH wind gusts across northeast Huron county, causing quite a bit of damage. The outflow created from the storms across the north actually held together long enough to spread south. There were several reports of trees blown down in areas south of M-59, although the damage was minimal when compared to the destruction across the northern parts of the area. Very few reports of hail were received, however, golf ball size hail was reported in Saginaw County. This event caused one death and one injury in Wayne County. A couple was struck by lightning after seeking refuge under a tree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported trees blown down and estimated wind gusts of 65 mph.
Several trees were blown down three miles north of Springfield.
Large trees were blown down in Decatur.
Law enforcement reported large trees were blown down in Scotts.
An emergency manager reported trees down and a tree blown down onto a house one mile west of Marshall.
Several large trees were blown down in Marshall.
State police reported that three inch diameter hail fell in and just east of Grand Junction and that hail covered the ground for a short duration.
Law enforcement reported that several trees were blown down across southern Mason county.
Several trees and power lines were blown down near Mears and Pentwater.

Hail lasted for five to ten minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This 2006 heat wave delivered the hottest weather the region had experienced in at least 4 years. A 5 day stretch of maximum temperatures at or above 90 degrees began on Saturday, July 29th. A blanket of especially high heat and oppressive humidity settled over the area on Monday, July 31st, and remained relentless through Wednesday, August 2nd. Temperatures soared above 90 by noon with heat indices over 100 degrees. Heat indices averaged between 105 and 110 degrees through the entire afternoon. Most significantly, Detroit Metro tied the all time record for the warmest minimum temperature, for any date, when it failed to record a temperature below 80 degrees on July 31st.  This had happened only 3 other times in the previous 136 years of record keeping, and this was the first time in 64 years that it had happened again. Detroit topped out at 97 and set a new high temperature record for August 1st,  tying the old record set in 1988. Little relief was felt during the evening with temperatures not dropping below 90 until 1900 EST. The major power companies in the area reported an all-time record customer demand for power from 1500 to 1600 EDT on the 1st, breaking the record that was set just the day before. Remarkably, very few heat related illnesses occurred during the event. Newspaper articles revealed an extremely high level of awareness and preparedness from the communities across southeast lower Michigan. A large number of cooling centers were made available to those in need as folks reportedly heeded the warnings and took extra precaution. Although area hospitals reported some increase due to heat related illnesses, most were mild and due to heat exhaustion and dehydration. Six cases of heatstroke were confirmed in Washtenaw, Wayne, and Macomb Counties. No heat related deaths were reported.

Washtenaw County Emergency Manager, trained spotters, and Michigan State Police all reported a weak tornado at the I94 and US23 interchange. The Tornado/cold air funnel was very brief and just kicked up some dirt with wind speeds estimated between 40 and 50 MPH. There were no injuries and no damages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported trees blown down in Midland. A local newspaper article also included a picture of a very large 80 foot honey locust tree lying on top of a home. The tree punched through the back sunroom of the home. A neighbor also lost a 50 foot cherry tree due to the thunderstorm winds. Several other large trees were reported blown down across the city of Midland. Midland County was hit particularly hard. Thousands of customers lost power, with most going without power for 3 to 4 days due to the extent of the tree damage across the region. The road commission responded to 24 calls of trees down across roadways. Midland firefighters responded to 50 storm related calls, most involving downed trees and power lines. The most damage in the city occurred from Nelson Street to the downtown area, and in the area of Nakoma Drive and Jefferson Avenue. At least one vehicle was damaged due to fallen debris. Property damage in the area was roughly estimated at around $50K.
A couple of trees were blown down onto power lines in Greenville.
Hundreds of trees were blown down across Oceana county.
Numerous trees were blown down along the Lake Michigan shoreline.
Many trees were blown down in and around Newaygo county.
Law enforcement reported that a couple of trees were blown down in Grand Ledge.
Law enforcement reported several trees were blown down in Lawrence.
A 51 knot gust was measured by the Lansing ASOS.
Law enforcement in Lawton reported several trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area during the evening of August 2nd and finally brought an end to the five day heat wave that had plagued southeast Michigan. Thunderstorms, a few intense, fired up out ahead of the cold front within the unstable airmass in place across southeast michigan. The severe weather was primarily confined to areas along and just south of the I-69 corridor. This was mainly a wind event with reports of several trees blown down. Most significantly, a tropical-like airmass and repeated rounds of storms along the I-69 corridor caused flash flooding in Lapeer and Sanilac counties, with extensive damages occurring in and around the Brown City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a tree top blown off and estimated the wind gusts at 65 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow intensified as a weak cold front moved southward across the region.  North-northwest winds behind the front produced locally heavy lake effect snow in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan.  Six to eight inches of snow fell in Lake Ann, Mapleton, and Kewadin.  A very isolated eight inches of snowfall also occurred in Paradise in Eastern Upper Michigan.

Strong northwest winds gusting as high as 35 to 45 mph brought heavy effect snow and considerable blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 6th continuing into the 7th.  The Munising Public Schools, AuTrain-Onota and Superior Central Schools were all closed in Alger County on the 7th due to the heavy snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts in 24-hours included 10 inches at the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township and at Shot Point. Considerable blowing and drifting of snow was reported especially along Lake Superior.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was reported in Rock with occasional whiteouts from blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds gusting as high as 35 to 45 mph brought heavy effect snow and considerable blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 6th continuing into the 7th.  The Munising Public Schools, AuTrain-Onota and Superior Central Schools were all closed in Alger County on the 7th due to the heavy snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow was reported in 12 hours at the Seney Post Office.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds gusting as high as 35 to 45 mph brought heavy effect snow and considerable blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 6th continuing into the 7th.  The Munising Public Schools, AuTrain-Onota and Superior Central Schools were all closed in Alger County on the 7th due to the heavy snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 24-hour snowfall totals of 10 inches 13 miles south of Grand Marais and 8-10 inches at Autrain.  Northwest winds gusting to 45 mph at times caused frequent whiteout conditions especially along Lake Superior.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving low pressure system and it's attendant cold front brought an early October severe weather episode with numerous reports of large hail and several reports of high winds with severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inch diameter hail was reported three miles east southeast of Shepherd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds gusting as high as 35 to 45 mph brought heavy effect snow and considerable blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 6th continuing into the 7th.  The Munising Public Schools, AuTrain-Onota and Superior Central Schools were all closed in Alger County on the 7th due to the heavy snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of six inches of snow in 12 hours were received from Ewen, Rockland and just inland from Ontonagon.  Gusty northwest winds contributed to occasional whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level disturbance produced a period of intense snowfall across most of Northern Lower Michigan, centered on the evening of the 10th.  Thunder and lightning accompanied the snow for several hours.  The snow was very sloppy and wet, with snow-to-liquid ratios around 6 to 1.  Thus, though the precipitation was heavy, snowfall amounts were generally only 3 to 6 inches, or a bit under warning criteria.  However, the weight of the snow brought down a number of tree limbs and power lines across the region.  Parts of Presque Isle, Wexford, and Missaukee Counties were without power for 48 hours.

Heavy lake effect snow plummeled the Wakefield area late on the 22nd into the afternoon of the 23rd. Snowfall totals of 13 to 16 inches were reported throughout the city with snowfall rates of nearly two inches per hour at times.  Gogebic Community College cancelled classes and other events on the evening of the 23rd due to the heavy snow. The Wakefield city council meeting was also cancelled on the 23rd for the first time in at least 20 years due to weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 13 to 16 inches reported in the Wakefield area.  Nine inches of snow reportedly fell during a five-hour period from 8 am to 1 pm on the 23rd.

A storm system originating in the Plains moved into the Lower Great Lakes on the 10th.  This system brought a swath of heavy, wet snow to portions of south central Upper Michigan.  Poor visibility and snowpacked highways were blamed for numerous traffic accidents during the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to seven inches of snowfall was observed near LaBranche and over the northern third of Menominee County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of snowfall was measured at Cooks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Hardwood and just north of Iron Mountain measured nine inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred over portions of Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from sunrise on the 2nd to sunrise on the 3rd. Locations from near Melstrand to 13 miles south of Grand Marais received over a foot of snow while 10 inches of snow was measured near Pine Stump Junction in Luce County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported ten to thirteen inches of snow along Highway M-77 near the Alger County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds gusting as high as 35 to 45 mph brought heavy effect snow and considerable blowing snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 6th continuing into the 7th.  The Munising Public Schools, AuTrain-Onota and Superior Central Schools were all closed in Alger County on the 7th due to the heavy snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snowfall was observed in Ironwood in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering low pressure trough over southern Lake Superior dropped heavy lake effect snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 12-hour snowfall amounts of 18 inches in Marenisco and 13 inches in Wakefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in the afternoon in Northern Lower Michigan, ahead of an approaching cold front.  Some storms became severe, producing large hail.

A prefrontal trough provided the focus for thunderstorm development that moved south into far southern Lower Michigan. An isolated storm produced severe wind gusts as a result of a wet microburst.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down in Union City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in the afternoon in Northern Lower Michigan, ahead of an approaching cold front.  Some storms became severe, producing large hail.

A somewhat disorganized band of thunderstorms developed, ahead of a fast-moving cold front.  These storms crossed Northern Lower Michigan in the late evening and early overnight hours, producing very large hail, some damaging winds, and a brief tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines downed around Higgins Lake.

A strong early winter season low pressure system brought snow and freezing rain to southwestern and west central lower Michigan. The heaviest ice accumulations occurred over southern lower Michigan south of I-96 where many locations reported at least three tenths of an inch of ice.  Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches along and near I-96, and 6 to 9 inches north of a line from Grand Haven to Alma.  Heaviest snowfall was reported in Mason and Oceana counties where up to 12 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three tenths of an inch of ice accumulation was reported at 6 am and three to fiven inches of snow fell later in the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong early winter season low pressure system brought snow and freezing rain to southwestern and west central lower Michigan. The heaviest ice accumulations occurred over southern lower Michigan south of I-96 where many locations reported at least three tenths of an inch of ice.  Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches along and near I-96, and 6 to 9 inches north of a line from Grand Haven to Alma.  Heaviest snowfall was reported in Mason and Oceana counties where up to 12 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three tenths of an inch of ice was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed across far western lower Michigan behind another Alberta clipper system which moved through the area.  Up to 20 inches of snow fell across portions of Van Buren county in less than 24 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to 20 inches of snow was reported near the Lake Michigan shoreline in far western Van Buren county in the communities of Bloomingdale and Grand Junction.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system brought a combination of synoptic snow followed by lake effect snow behind it to far western lower Michigan from December 4th through the 5th.  Most of the snow fell from the mid morning hours of the 4th through the very late evening hours on the 4th.  The heaviest snowfall was reported from Holland to South Haven near route 31 where eleven inch snowfall reports were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to eight inches of snow was reported.

Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches along and near I-96, and 6 to 9 inches north of a line from Grand Haven to Alma.  Heaviest snowfall was reported in Mason and Oceana counties where up to 12 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine to twelve inches of snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong early winter season low pressure system brought snow and freezing rain to southwestern and west central lower Michigan. The heaviest ice accumulations occurred over southern lower Michigan south of I-96 where many locations reported at least three tenths of an inch of ice.  Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches along and near I-96, and 6 to 9 inches north of a line from Grand Haven to Alma.  Heaviest snowfall was reported in Mason and Oceana counties where up to 12 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three tenths of an inch of ice accumulation occurred along with five to six inches of snow later in the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper system brought lake enhanced and lake effect snow to the region.  The heaviest snow occured with southwest winds on Lake Michigan, producing very heavy snow in Mackinac County.  Some places between St Ignace and Moran picked up a foot of snow in just 5 hours near midday on the 4th.  The slick roads and near-zero visibility resulted in numerous accidents on US-2, I-75, and M-123 in Mackinac County.  Those roads were shut down by the state police for a few hours in the afternoon.  In Northwest Lower Michigan, the snow was not quite as intense, but lasted much longer, as lake effect snow continued when winds turned northwest behind the departing clipper.  Wellston and Lake Ann both ended up with a foot of snow by the morning of the 5th, while Alden had 10 inches.

A period of freezing rain and sleet had a minimal to moderate impact on central and northern sections of Southeast Michigan. Parts of the Tri-Cities area received over an inch of sleet and up to 2 inches of snow, leading to multiple spin-outs. |Farther south, more freezing rain was observed, where ice accumulated up to 1/2 an inch on vegetative and elevated surfaces along the I-69 corridor. Lesser amounts of ice accumulated along the M-59 corridor. Although roads in these areas remained wet and traffic impacts were minimal, numerous tree branches and power lines were downed due to the weight of the ice, leading to sporadic power outages. No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 1/4 inch ice accumulations on vegetative and elevated surfaces across the west half of Tuscola County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of freezing rain and sleet had a minimal to moderate impact on central and northern sections of Southeast Michigan. Parts of the Tri-Cities area received over an inch of sleet and up to 2 inches of snow, leading to multiple spin-outs. |Farther south, more freezing rain was observed, where ice accumulated up to 1/2 an inch on vegetative and elevated surfaces along the I-69 corridor. Lesser amounts of ice accumulated along the M-59 corridor. Although roads in these areas remained wet and traffic impacts were minimal, numerous tree branches and power lines were downed due to the weight of the ice, leading to sporadic power outages. No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cooperative observers and trained spotters reported 4/10 of an inch of ice accumulations on vegetative and elevated surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifted northeast from Oklahoma across Southeast Lower Michigan.  Heavy snow occurred to the left of the track of the low.  Northerly winds allowed Lake Michigan to enhance the snowfall somewhat, with the heaviest snow near the coastline.  Manistee picked up almost 17 inches of snow.  Away from the lakeshore, most of Northern Lower Michigan received 5 to 10 inches of snow.  Some blowing and drifting snow developed late on the 1st, as winds kicked up when the system departed.  The intense snowfall contributed to a number of accidents on area roads.  Many schools in the region let out early to try to beat the worst of the conditions.

An extended period of northwest winds brought locally heavy lake effect snow.  The snow was enhanced by an upper level disturbance that passed through the area.  The M-66 corridor got the worst of it, with 10 to 18 inches of snowfall from East Jordan to a bit north of Lake City.

A cold front ushered in colder air across the relatively warm waters of the Great Lakes, resulting in several bands of lake effect snow showers. One dominant band set up from far southwestern Michigan into Northern Indiana. Amounts ranged from 11 inches in Marcellus to 7 inches in Cassopolis, to 6 inches in White Pigeon, Sturgis and Union.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A persistent band of moderate to heavy lake effect snow dumped 11 inches in Marcellus, 7 inches in Cassopolis and 6 inches in Jones and Union.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved northeast through the Ohio Valley into the eastern Great Lakes and produced moderate to heavy rainfall across the region. Surface temperatures dropped to at or below freezing across southern lower Michigan, resulting in freezing rain. Numerous tree limbs were downed by ice accumulations with the Benton Harbor automated weather system reporting 0.43 inches of freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small tree limbs down due to ice accumulation. 0.43 inches of freezing rain reported at Benton Harbor.

Although roads in these areas remained wet and traffic impacts were minimal, numerous tree branches and power lines were downed due to the weight of the ice, leading to sporadic power outages. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifted northeast from Oklahoma across Southeast Lower Michigan.  Heavy snow occurred to the left of the track of the low.  Northerly winds allowed Lake Michigan to enhance the snowfall somewhat, with the heaviest snow near the coastline.  Manistee picked up almost 17 inches of snow.  Away from the lakeshore, most of Northern Lower Michigan received 5 to 10 inches of snow.  Some blowing and drifting snow developed late on the 1st, as winds kicked up when the system departed.  The intense snowfall contributed to a number of accidents on area roads.  Many schools in the region let out early to try to beat the worst of the conditions.

Freezing rain and freezing drizzle developed over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the 14th in advance of a low pressure system moving in from Minnesota.  Icy roads caused numerous accidents in Iron and Dickinson county and closed some schools early in Iron County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain or freezing drizzle created slippery road conditions and caused several accidents in the Iron Mountain-Kingford area. |A Norway woman lost control and rolled her vehicle on Highway US-8. |She was transported by ambulance to Dickinson County Memorial Hospital where she was treated and released.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle developed over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the 14th in advance of a low pressure system moving in from Minnesota.  Icy roads caused numerous accidents in Iron and Dickinson county and closed some schools early in Iron County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle contributed to numerous accidents in Iron County on the 14th and caused the early dismissal of students from Forest Park and West Iron County schools.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds with gusts to 53 MPH brought down tree limbs and power lines, taking out power to thousands, especially across the Detroit area.  A strong low pressure system that tracked across southeast Michigan was to blame. Winds increased rapidly around 1200 EST with sustained winds at 25 to 35 MPH and higher gusts lasting for a period of several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 45 MPH across southern sections of Oakland County were blamed for knocking out power to about 1,000 customers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light wintry mix of precipitation developed ahead of an approaching low pressure system over the Plains.  A light glaze of freezing drizzle and sleet produced slippery surfaces across southern Houghton, Iron, Dickinson and Marquette counties on the evening of the 21st continuing into the 22nd.  Several traffic accidents were reported in Dickinson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic light freezing drizzle reported at Green Garden and the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light wintry mix of precipitation developed ahead of an approaching low pressure system over the Plains.  A light glaze of freezing drizzle and sleet produced slippery surfaces across southern Houghton, Iron, Dickinson and Marquette counties on the evening of the 21st continuing into the 22nd.  Several traffic accidents were reported in Dickinson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic freezing drizzle and sleet reported by observers near Norway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering low pressure trough over southern Lake Superior dropped heavy lake effect snow over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Toivola reported eight inches of snowfall in 12 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic freezing drizzle reported by an observer south of Kenton across the Iron County border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light wintry mix of precipitation developed ahead of an approaching low pressure system over the Plains.  A light glaze of freezing drizzle and sleet produced slippery surfaces across southern Houghton, Iron, Dickinson and Marquette counties on the evening of the 21st continuing into the 22nd.  Several traffic accidents were reported in Dickinson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic freezing drizzle reported by an observer south of Kenton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system developing over the central Plains tracked into eastern Lake Superior early on the 23rd. This system dumped heavy snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd continuing into the morning of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches in 12 hours observed by a spotter in the vicinity of Nisula.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure system set up a favorable situation for fog formation. Light winds off of Lake Erie and Lake St Clair carried a marine layer of low clouds and dense fog inland across the Detroit area, mainly along and south of I-94. Visibilities were near zero at times during the rush hour traffic. Temperatures in the 20's allowed the dense fog to freeze on area roadways, creating slippery conditions and numerous accidents. By 1000 EST, temperatures had climbed above freezing and visibilities had begun to improve.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing fog, accompanied by near zero visibilities, created very slippery  conditions on area roads. This led to numerous accidents during the morning rush hour traffic. A semi-truck rollover accident at the northbound I-75 and I-275 junction resulted in the death of a person (indirect) at about 0800 EST. The road was closed for several hours as clean-up operations at the scene were hampered by the dense fog.

A period of freezing rain and sleet had a minimal to moderate impact on central and northern sections of Southeast Michigan. Parts of the Tri-Cities area received over an inch of sleet and up to 2 inches of snow, leading to multiple spin-outs. |Farther south, more freezing rain was observed, where ice accumulated up to 1/2 an inch on vegetative and elevated surfaces along the I-69 corridor. Lesser amounts of ice accumulated along the M-59 corridor. Although roads in these areas remained wet and traffic impacts were minimal, numerous tree branches and power lines were downed due to the weight of the ice, leading to sporadic power outages. No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported icing up to 2/10 of an inch on vegetative and elevated surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds with gusts to 53 MPH brought down tree limbs and power lines, taking out power to thousands, especially across the Detroit area.  A strong low pressure system that tracked across southeast Michigan was to blame. Winds increased rapidly around 1200 EST with sustained winds at 25 to 35 MPH and higher gusts lasting for a period of several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts measured over 50 MPH were blamed for knocking out power to 31,000 customers in Wayne County. At 1300 EST, official observing equipment at the Detroit Metro Airport measured sustained winds of 40 MPH and a peak wind gust at 53 MPH. Total property damages were roughly estimated at $20K for the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds with gusts to 53 MPH brought down tree limbs and power lines, taking out power to thousands, especially across the Detroit area.  A strong low pressure system that tracked across southeast Michigan was to blame. Winds increased rapidly around 1200 EST with sustained winds at 25 to 35 MPH and higher gusts lasting for a period of several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gusts of 43 MPH at Ann Arbor and 54 MPH at Ypsilanti were officially recorded by automatic observing equipment around 1300 EST. The wind was to blame for knocking out power to 2,500 customers in Washtenaw County. Four parked cars at Ann Arbor's Briarwood Mall were damaged at 1215 EST when a light pole broke at the base because of the wind. Total property damages throughout the county were roughly estimated at $15K. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong early winter season low pressure system brought snow and freezing rain to southwestern and west central lower Michigan. The heaviest ice accumulations occurred over southern lower Michigan south of I-96 where many locations reported at least three tenths of an inch of ice.  Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches along and near I-96, and 6 to 9 inches north of a line from Grand Haven to Alma.  Heaviest snowfall was reported in Mason and Oceana counties where up to 12 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A third of an inch of ice was reported across most of Ionia county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed way out ahead of a cold front and dropped southeast into the Saginaw Valley and Thumb. This late season event occurred at night with intense lightning strikes and damaging wind gusts.

A complex of thunderstorms moved across the region resulting in one severe hail report.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a home, creating a small hole in the roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of thunderstorms moved across the region resulting in one severe hail report.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper included a picture of a home that caught fire after being struck by lightning. The blaze resulted in extensive damages, destroying two second-story rooms and the roof. Property damages were estimated at $150K. No one was injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of thunderstorms moved across the region resulting in one severe hail report.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper included a picture of a condominium that caught fire after being struck by lightning. The blaze caused extensive damage to the condo, including the entire interior. Other condos attached to this one were not damaged. Damages were roughly estimated at $50K. No one was injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and cold low pressure system settled southward from the Canadian Arctic.  Unseasonably cold air allowed precipitation to turn to snow, particularly away from the Lake Michigan shoreline (where warm water temperatures resulted in more rain and less snow).  The heaviest snow was lake enhanced, and thus somewhat isolated.  DeTour Village picked up nearly a foot of snow, as did Cheboygan.  A brief period of thunder and lightning occurred with the heavy snow in this region.  The heavy, wet snow caused a tree to fall on a major transmission line, knocking out power to almost all of Eastern Upper Michigan, east of M-129, for several hours.  An additional area of 6 to 8 inches of snow fell from Kingsley and Fife Lake, eastward across much of Kalkaska County.  Local power outages, caused by fallen tree limbs, were also reported in isolated areas across Northern Lower Michigan.

A strong low pressure system developing over the Plains moved through the Upper Great Lakes on the 10th and then into Ontario on the 11th. Gusty west to northwest winds in excess of 30 mph in the wake of the low brought heavy lake effect snow showers to portions of western Upper Michigan from the 11th through the 13th. In addition to the snow, there were localized wind gusts over 50 mph reported in northern Houghton county on the evening of the 12th.  |Heavy lake effect snow closed schools in Baraga on the 12th and some schools in Gogebic and Ontonagon counties on the 13th. Minor traffic accidents were also reported in Ontonagon and Gogebic counties due to the snowpacked highways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches of snowfall measured in 12 hours at Mohawk and ten inches measured in 24 hours in higher terrain near Eagle River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through Upper Michigan on the morning of the 31th. West winds behind the front gusted near 60 mph over the higher terrain of the Keweenaw Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 50 knots extrapolated over higher terrain north of Calumet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall reports included 14 inches at Marenisco and 10 inches or more in the Ironwood area. Eight inches of snowfall in 12 hours was observed in Marenisco ending on the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts measured at 58 mph at the Houghton County Airport ASOS. Wind gusts of 63 mph also measured by the wind sensor at the Keweenaw Research Center in Calumet.

Localized wind gusts of 45 mph were measured by the ASOS at the Houghton County airport on the evening of the 11th, while a wind gust to 52 mph was reported by a spotter at Freda.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A somewhat disorganized band of thunderstorms developed, ahead of a fast-moving cold front.  These storms crossed Northern Lower Michigan in the late evening and early overnight hours, producing very large hail, some damaging winds, and a brief tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several hundred trees were downed at Manistee National Golf Course and the surrounding area.  One large tree was downed onto a truck.  A window was blown out of a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A somewhat disorganized band of thunderstorms developed, ahead of a fast-moving cold front.  These storms crossed Northern Lower Michigan in the late evening and early overnight hours, producing very large hail, some damaging winds, and a brief tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado occurred west of Cadillac, along Benson Road just south of M-55.  A garage and part of a kitchen was ripped off of a home and destroyed.  The owner was asleep in a bedroom on the other side of the house, and was not injured.  An aluminum shed in the yard was wrapped around a tree.  A home across the street was shifted slightly off its foundation.  A few other nearby homes suffered shingle damage.  Several large pine trees were uprooted.
